dspace-development.title: Import dissertations MARC records for June and September 2020 into DataSpace

comments.body:
The following feedback was provided by Mark Zelesky while advancing this batch import:

> I'm encountering some ARKs in the dissertation records that are not resolving properly. The issue seems to be the ARK resolving to an http:// URL instead of https://
> For example, http://arks.princeton.edu/ark:/88435/dsp01hx11xj16g resolves to http://dataspace.princeton.edu/jspui/handle/88435/dsp01hx11xj16g
> When I force it to be https://dataspace.princeton.edu/jspui/handle/88435/dsp01hx11xj16g, it loads.

> I also noticed odd characters in some of the 856$u values (horizontal tab character), so I'll clean those up too. And some just have a URL of 'NO_ARK_FOUND'. I'll remove those too, since those links won't work.

Add persister to generate mosaic on complete
DaoUpdateJob fails when an archival object is not found

comments.body: Definitely the same as #4902

Rescue the error and send a notification to Honeybadger (honeybadger.notify) saying:
- If the source metadata identifier looks like a component id (e.g. MC001), talk to the product owner
- Otherwise, ask on the figgy slack channel if anyone recognizes what's going on

figgy.title: Consider making FileAppender raise an error again, rather than swallowing them

comments.body:
I think the reasoning here is that if a bunch of files go fine but then one file errors and raises, we would end up with a bunch of orphaned file sets and uploaded files that we then re-do.

What if we use Honeybadger.notify instead of raising the error again? This way we'll know it happened and someone can intervene to either fix it or delete the whole resource. @tpendragon @eliotjordan If it's too noisy we can re-evaluate.

I think you'd end up with orphaned binaries, but no database entries. That's a good concern though.

I'm concerned about more network-related issues causing a bunch of broken files that could have been automatically fixed more than I am some disk space being used, I think? You're right though that it depends on how often this kind of thing happens.
Hm. If we're going to have orphaned binaries, then maybe I'd rather have them attached to orphaned database entries.

I'm behind your suggestion - rescue and notify Honeybadger and keep an eye on it. If we're finding that we're constantly going in and manually digging up files to add because of network issues or something we should consider letting it all fail and just paying the cost of stranded binaries.

pul_solr.title: Ensure each collection has at least 2 replicas

comments.body: dss-prod1 & special-collections-prod1 were deleted infavaor of dss-prod2 and special-collections-prod2, which have a replication factor of 2

The replicationfactor can be updated from the box with a curl command like, e.g.:
`curl "http://localhost:8983/solr/admin/collections?action=MODIFYCOLLECTION&collection=pulmap&replicationFactor=2"`

Then another replica added like, e.g.:
`curl "http://localhost:8983/solr/admin/collections?action=ADDREPLICA&collection=pulmap&shard=shard1"`

rdss-catchall.title: Fix rsolr CI process and review PRs

comments.body: This is done.

ProQuest says they cannot connect to our system since 25 Jan 2021:

```
Hi Bess,

Thanks for reaching back out. It looks like this is the most recent update from the dev Team:

"It does look like there have been failures since attempting to deliver starting 1/25.  I checked the connection and am getting this:

Connecting to proquestdrop.pulcloud.io...
no hostkey alg
Couldn't read packet: Connection reset by peer"

What are your current settings?

Sincerely,
Carl
```

That `No hostkey alg` makes me wonder if we need to fix some settings in our sshd, per this stackexchange thread:

https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/679451/sshd-no-hostkey-alg-fixed-but-still-confused

Based on the above thread, I connected to the system and manually edited `/etc/ssh/sshd_config` to ensure that we use an RSA hostkey (previously all hostkey configuration was commented out), and that the RSA hostkey algorithm is explicitly configured. I've asked ProQuest to try again, and if it still isn't working I've requested an appointment for a real-time phone call to troubleshoot.

default behavior of OpenSSH is not to load [HostCertificate](https://man.openbsd.org/sshd_config) This suggests the client initiating the request is the likely source of the problem. The change will generate a MITM warning that can be ignored or if paranoid can ask us for verification.
